I.Â INTRODUCTIONÂ Â
DemandÂ forÂ socialÂ protectionÂ isÂ growingÂ inÂ lowÂ incomeÂ countriesÂ andÂ fragileÂ situations.Â InÂ recentÂ years,Â theÂ successÂ ofÂ socialÂ protectionÂ interventionsÂ inÂ middleÂ incomeÂ countriesÂ (MICs)Â suchÂ asÂ BrazilÂ andÂ Mexico,Â alongÂ withÂ theÂ seriesÂ ofÂ food,Â fuel,Â andÂ financialÂ crises,Â hasÂ promptedÂ policymakersÂ inÂ lowÂ incomeÂ countriesÂ (LICs)Â andÂ fragileÂ situationsÂ (FSs)Â toÂ examineÂ theÂ possibilityÂ ofÂ introducingÂ suchÂ programsÂ inÂ theirÂ ownÂ countries.Â TheÂ prominenceÂ ofÂ flagshipÂ programsÂ includingÂ Ethiopiaâ€™sÂ ProductiveÂ SafetyÂ NetsÂ ProgramÂ andÂ Indiaâ€™sÂ NationalÂ RuralÂ EmploymentÂ GuaranteeÂ ActÂ hasÂ increasedÂ expectationsÂ aboutÂ theÂ feasibilityÂ ofÂ customizingÂ socialÂ protectionÂ systemsÂ inÂ countriesÂ withÂ lowÂ capacity.Â AtÂ theÂ sameÂ time,Â momentumÂ isÂ shiftingÂ towardÂ supportÂ isÂ growingÂ forÂ theÂ ideaÂ thatÂ theÂ provisionÂ ofÂ essentialÂ socialÂ transfersÂ andÂ servicesÂ byÂ countriesÂ toÂ theirÂ peopleÂ isÂ aÂ basicÂ humanÂ rightÂ asÂ isÂ spelledÂ outÂ inÂ theÂ UNÂ SocialÂ ProtectionÂ FloorÂ Initiative,Â asÂ adoptedÂ byÂ theÂ ChiefÂ ExecutivesÂ BoardÂ ofÂ theÂ UnitedÂ NationsÂ inÂ AprilÂ 2009.Â
NationalÂ governmentsÂ areÂ increasinglyÂ lookingÂ atÂ socialÂ protectionÂ toÂ shieldÂ theirÂ populationsÂ againstÂ shocks,Â alleviateÂ poverty,Â andÂ promoteÂ economicÂ growth.Â EvidenceÂ showsÂ thatÂ effective,Â efficient,Â andÂ equitableÂ socialÂ protectionÂ programsÂ canÂ directlyÂ reduceÂ povertyÂ andÂ inequalityÂ andÂ helpÂ familiesÂ becomeÂ moreÂ resilientÂ byÂ enablingÂ themÂ toÂ smoothÂ consumptionÂ andÂ manageÂ shocks.Â SocialÂ protectionÂ andÂ laborÂ policiesÂ alsoÂ promoteÂ opportunity,Â productivity,Â andÂ growth,Â notablyÂ byÂ buildingÂ andÂ protectingÂ humanÂ capitalÂ assets,Â increasingÂ accessÂ toÂ jobs,Â andÂ freeingÂ familiesÂ toÂ makeÂ productiveÂ investmentsÂ withÂ higherÂ returnsÂ becauseÂ ofÂ aÂ greaterÂ senseÂ ofÂ security.Â InÂ fragileÂ situations,Â socialÂ protectionÂ canÂ alsoÂ promoteÂ socialÂ cohesionÂ byÂ supportingÂ widowsÂ andÂ orphansÂ andÂ rehabilitatingÂ exâ€? combatantsÂ andÂ peopleÂ whoÂ haveÂ beenÂ disabledÂ inÂ war.Â Â
InnovativeÂ technologyÂ solutionsÂ andÂ theÂ exchangeÂ ofÂ knowledgeÂ amongÂ nationsÂ areÂ helpingÂ deliverÂ socialÂ protectionÂ inÂ countriesÂ withÂ differentÂ levelsÂ ofÂ capacity.Â InÂ someÂ
1Â countries,Â governmentsÂ areÂ becomingÂ interestedÂ inÂ combiningÂ separateÂ socialÂ protectionÂ programsÂ intoÂ integratedÂ socialÂ protectionÂ systems.Â InnovativeÂ ITÂ solutionsÂ suchÂ asÂ smartÂ cardsÂ andÂ mobileÂ phonesÂ canÂ improveÂ theÂ deliveryÂ andÂ increaseÂ theÂ accountabilityÂ ofÂ socialÂ protectionÂ programs,Â spurringÂ greaterÂ interestÂ inÂ lowÂ incomeÂ countriesÂ inÂ developingÂ commonÂ administrativeÂ systems.Â Southâ€?SouthÂ exchangesÂ andÂ globalÂ recognitionÂ ofÂ theÂ importantÂ roleÂ playedÂ byÂ socialÂ protectionÂ inÂ improvingÂ theÂ welfareÂ ofÂ theÂ poorestÂ citizensÂ areÂ alsoÂ supportingÂ thisÂ shift.Â InÂ fragileÂ situations,Â theÂ focusÂ isÂ necessarilyÂ onÂ strengtheningÂ theÂ stateÂ itselfÂ andÂ itsÂ institutions.Â AsÂ such,Â socialÂ protectionÂ isÂ seenÂ asÂ essentialÂ bothÂ toÂ buildÂ institutionsÂ andÂ toÂ protectÂ theÂ vulnerable.Â Therefore,Â theÂ natureÂ ofÂ socialÂ protectionÂ inÂ fragileÂ andÂ postâ€?conflictÂ statesÂ isÂ oftenÂ quiteÂ differentÂ fromÂ thatÂ inÂ LICs.Â
DespiteÂ growingÂ levelsÂ ofÂ politicalÂ supportÂ andÂ innovation,Â challengesÂ remain.Â SocialÂ protectionÂ inÂ lowÂ incomeÂ andÂ fragileÂ situationsÂ is,Â forÂ theÂ mostÂ part,Â stillÂ atÂ anÂ earlyÂ orÂ experimentalÂ stage.Â SomeÂ argueÂ thatÂ theseÂ countriesÂ areÂ tooÂ poorÂ toÂ investÂ scarceÂ resourcesÂ inÂ socialÂ protectionÂ programs.Â ThisÂ viewÂ isÂ drivenÂ byÂ theÂ beliefÂ thatÂ socialÂ protectionÂ isÂ aÂ â€œhandoutâ€?Â ratherÂ thanÂ anÂ investmentÂ inÂ economicÂ growth.Â SocialÂ protectionÂ programsÂ areÂ viewedÂ byÂ someÂ asÂ fiscallyÂ unsustainableÂ andÂ asÂ creatingÂ dependencyÂ inÂ recipientsÂ whoÂ hadÂ previouslyÂ reliedÂ onÂ informalÂ safetyÂ nets.Â OnÂ theÂ otherÂ hand,Â someÂ lowÂ incomeÂ andÂ fragileÂ countriesÂ haveÂ fullyÂ embracedÂ socialÂ protectionÂ andÂ madeÂ itÂ aÂ keyÂ pillarÂ inÂ theirÂ developmentÂ strategies,Â recognizingÂ itÂ asÂ aÂ criticalÂ foundationÂ forÂ sharedÂ growthÂ andÂ socialÂ stability.Â
DevelopingÂ andÂ deliveringÂ effectiveÂ SPÂ inÂ lowÂ incomeÂ countriesÂ andÂ fragileÂ situationsÂ presentsÂ operationalÂ challenges.Â TheÂ depthÂ andÂ breadthÂ ofÂ povertyÂ inÂ theseÂ countriesÂ isÂ muchÂ greaterÂ thanÂ inÂ otherÂ countries.Â TheÂ poorestÂ groupsÂ areÂ veryÂ difficultÂ toÂ identifyÂ andÂ reach;Â fiscalÂ resourcesÂ areÂ constrained;Â andÂ administrativeÂ capacityÂ toÂ implementÂ programsÂ isÂ weak,Â asÂ isÂ theÂ abilityÂ toÂ ensureÂ thatÂ programsÂ actuallyÂ reachÂ theirÂ intendedÂ recipients.Â ProgramsÂ areÂ oftenÂ easierÂ toÂ introduceÂ thanÂ toÂ reform.Â FragileÂ situationsÂ faceÂ evenÂ greaterÂ challenges,Â oftenÂ becauseÂ theirÂ insecureÂ territorialÂ situationÂ canÂ inhibitÂ bothÂ theÂ supplyÂ andÂ demandÂ forÂ socialÂ protectionÂ andÂ otherÂ services.Â Â

doc.repnme: Social protection in low income countries and fragile situations : challenges and future directions
doc.abstracts: Demand for social protection is growing in low income countries and fragile situations. In recent years, the success of social protection (SP) interventions in middle income countries (MICs) like Brazil and Mexico, along with the series of food, fuel, and financial crises, has prompted policymakers in low income countries (LICs) and fragile situations (FSs) to examine the possibility of introducing such programs in their own countries. Flagship programs in countries as diverse as Ethiopia, India, Pakistan, and Rwanda have shown the adaptability of social protection interventions to the LIC context. Yet, despite growing levels of support for these initiatives, many challenges remain. In LICs and FSs, governments are confronted with a nexus of mutually reinforcing deficits that increase the need for SP programs and simultaneously reduce their ability to successfully respond. Governments face hard choices about the type, affordability, and sustainability of SP interventions. The paper reviews how these factors affect SP programs in these countries and identifies ways to address the deficits. It supports the establishment of resilient SP systems to address specific needs and vulnerabilities and to respond flexibly to both slow and sudden onset crises. To achieve this, both innovation and pragmatism are required in three strategic areas: (i) building the basic blocks of SP systems (e.g., targeting, payments, and monitoring and evaluation); (ii) ensuring financial sustainability; and (iii) promoting good governance and transparency. These issues suggest the possibility of a different trajectory in the development of social protection in LICs than in MICs. The implications for World Bank support include the need to focus on increasing knowledge and operational effectiveness of SP programs, fostering institutional links between multiple SP programs, and using community capacity and technological innovations to overcome bottlenecks in operations.
